chapter.htmlHeader: What are the risk factors?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• The risk of experiencing domestic violence and abuse is increased if the person is [NICE, 2014]:
    • Female.
    • Aged 16–24 years (women) or 16–19 years (men).
    • Has a long-term illness, a disability, or a mental health problem — research published in 2013 showed that the odds of being a victim of domestic violence were two-fold higher for those with a physical disability and three-fold higher for those with a mental-illness-related disability [BMA, 2014].
    • Is a woman who is separated from her partner — there is a higher risk of abuse around the time of separation.
    • Is pregnant or has recently given birth — although pregnancy appears to offer protection for some women, it increases the risk for others. 
  • Other risk factors for domestic violence and abuse include:
    • Sexual orientation — about 80% of trans people (including cross-dressers, transgender and transsexual people, and other gender-variant people) experience emotional, physical, or sexual abuse from a partner or ex-partner, and 38.4% of bisexual, gay, and lesbian people class themselves as having experienced domestic violence and abuse [NICE, 2014]. 
    • Escalation of violence — previous domestic violence and abuse is the clearest indicator that further domestic violence and abuse will occur. Research shows that 35% of households have a second incident within five weeks of the first [DH, 2013].
    • Cultural factors — these include language barriers between partners, immigration status, isolation, and cultural beliefs (for example being from a female genital mutilation-practicing community) [DH, 2013].
    • Relative poverty — although domestic violence and abuse is experienced across all social classes, it has an economic gradient.
  • The role of alcohol or drug misuse in domestic violence and abuse is poorly understood [NICE, 2014].
    • According to the Home Office Statistical bulletin: Crime in England and Wales 2010/11, 21% of people experiencing partner abuse in the past year thought the perpetrator was under the influence of alcohol, and 8% under the influence of illicit drugs [Home Office, 2011].
